Topic.Title: Morgan Stanley Expects 6% Divy

Message.Msg: Here's the full article text: " Morgan Stanley expects 6% dividend, cheaper 'iPhone mini' after meeting with Apple CFO By Neil Hughes Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty recently met with Apple Chief Financial Officer Peter Oppenheimer, and came away with the impression that Apple will likely increase cash return to shareholders, and potentially release a lower priced iPhone to maintain growth. Huberty, in a note to investors on Friday, said that innovation remains a "top priority" at Apple. That's why she expects Apple to expand the iPhone lineup, and also to introduce new services that can "unlock significant value" and drive device sales. She noted that demand for the iPhone 4, Apple's current low-end handset offering, was surprisingly strong during the December quarter. With a gross margin of 40 percent and a one-third cannibalization rate, she believes a so-called "iPhone mini" would drive incremental revenue and gross profit. "The company's approach to product decisions and innovation has not changed in the past several years despite the CEO transition," Huberty wrote. "Making great products remains Apple's core strategy and the company is as confident as ever about the future pipeline of new products and services." And with Apple's cash balance $40 billion higher than it was in March of 2012, Huberty believes the company will likely return more cash to shareholders. She believes the iPhone maker could match the S&P 500 IT sector's average free cash flow payout of 68 percent. At that rate, Apple could return $28 billion to shareholders in fiscal year 2013, which would imply a 6 percent total yield on the company's dividend. That would be a major increase over Apple's current $2.65 quarterly dividend, which carries a 2.3 percent yield. To pay out that higher dividend, Apple could borrow cash. She noted that the amount of Apple's cash overseas has limited the company's flexibility, but this could be addressed by raising low-interest debt. Morgan Stanley has maintained its "overweight" rating for AAPL stock with a price target of $630. "

Message.Msg: Whatever happens, at least now something will happen. The tone Cook has taken has not inspired confidence in either the stock or AAPL products. I do own and recognize the superior value of AAPL products, however Cook has had 1 1/2 years at the helm. I believe the central issue here is that Cook has merely updated the existing product line, and has not brought a new product to market. His oversight of these product updates was marred by iMaps and the inability to ship product due to supply chain issues. If not new products, then what plans does AAPL have in regards to media acquisition, their own search engine, a much more aggressive program of emerging market retail store openings, etc. I'm sure many others could come up with other opportunities, but my point here is that Cook has been COMPLACENT in forging into the areas that would greatly enrich the AAPL ecosystem. Cook does not have vision. He has been and will only "captain" the ship with a "steady as she goes". Cook has inspired no one. Funds and retail recognize this. Here's hoping that the BOD smacks him one and he either leverages AAPL's clout or he is removed. Jobs wife said that Jobs could replace anyone, with the exception of Jony Ive. AAPL is creativity. Ive embodies that. Cook defines "boredom". Not what AAPL needs make their past success seem modest in comparison with the opportunities in front of them. Perhaps Jobs saw in Cook a manager that would provide a transition after his passing and maintain the course. I don't think he intended for Cook to be a permanent solution.

Message.Title: Apple will be a $610 billion revenue company by 2015
Message.Msg: Apple will be a $610 billion revenue company by 2015 as all their key markets start to experience hyper-growth. At the same time, it’s likely the best single metric to watch in the coming years will be price-to-sales. I expect Wall Street to (correctly) get more skeptical that Apple can keep growing its revenues beyond the boom in the next few years. Apple’s price-to-sales ratio (trailing) is currently 4x. I see it trending down gradually to 2.5x by 2015. Even with that compressed ratio, Apple can easily become a $1.53 trillion company by 2015. That’s $1,650 a share.

Message.Msg: First, I don't think it would be wise to use that much cash, they aren't going to do that. Second, they can't do it without repatriating cash from overseas which hasn't been taxed in the US. If they bring it back to buy stock then they have to pay the additional tax spread between the US rate and the rate where they have it parked. Not going to happen. At best they can borrow here at low rates and use that instead of incurring the tax hit on repatriation which would be disastrous to the stock price.

Message.Title: Forbes Article...
Message.Msg: Consultant: Cable companies won't allow that rumored Apple TV settop box Why? 1. There’s no way cable companies will give up control of the user experience to Apple. 2. If a pay TV operator decided to let Apple slap a new TV interface atop subscribers’ channel lineup on an Apple settop box, it would further expose to viewers how much they’re paying for channels they don’t watch. Non-sports fans are subsidizing sports fans with their ever-rising cable bills because ESPN and other sports content is so expensive to cable operators. “That’s the dirty little secret in the pay TV business” Richmond notes. And making it more obvious will only cause more viewers to demand a la carte subscriptions, threatening the bundle of channels that keeps studios and cable operators making billions. 3. Pay TV companies are strong financial shape, unlike the music business was, so it has no reason to change the status quo. “The TV industry has no real incentive to reach out for a white knight like Apple,” Richmond says. Correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't Comcast the parent company of CNBC? All the bashing...

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Apple’s (AAPL) iPhone isn’t just the best-selling smartphone in the world, it’s also the most reliable. A new study conducted by the company behind the community based trouble-shooting resource FixYa on Friday issued its latest smartphone reliability study. The study used data from 722,558 combined problem reports combined with market share data from StatCounter to assign a reliability score to leading smartphone vendor. Apple was found to be the most reliable handset maker with a score of 3.47, nearly 300% better than smartphone shipment volume leader Samsung (005930), which got a score of 1.21.

Message.Title: All APPS for Free Strategy - Think About It
Message.Msg: Fact : Apple has now paid out $8 billion to developers and reaped $3.5 revenue for themselves. Maybe the strategy needs to be changed. For example, agree on a purchase price for the developers App, Pay them a portion up front based on a target number of downloads over a 1-2 year period. Don't hit the target, no balance due. Hit the target and get paid the balance. Tie in exclusivity to Apple for a period of time if its deemed worthwhile for the specific App. Maintenance support the responsibility of the developer for a fixed time frame. This is just a general white paper thought - more terms, conditions, performance, bonuses, etc would need to be added. Now, what's the benefit here ? Well here are a few: Exclusivity is an asset. Don't have an Apple device, don't have the App - from anywhere. Support the smaller developers who need the money now in order to expand their business. Eight billion over 5 years? That's not much relative to the revenue / profits of the recruitment of customers that have competitive choices with a growing App inventory. Blocked out !!! What could that be worth ? Hey, Google did a job on Apple with its free-to-the world OS - think it would be nice to cause them a bit of struggle with their Motorola offerings. And it would now cost the other imitators for what they got for free. There is no free. If there is, it's probably not worth too often. Apples got to get tough - the game surely is.

Topic.Title: Morgan Stanley: Oppenheimer To Sell Debt And Raise Yield To 6%

Message.Msg: February 13, 2013, 3:19 P.M. ET AAPL: A 6% Yield, $28B Annually, Is Possible, Says Morgan Stanley By Tiernan Ray Morgan Stanley’s Katy Huberty today opines that a higher cash return from Apple (AAPL) could be a “catalyst” for the shares, writing that Apple’s projected return of free cash flow of 36%, between dividends and buybacks, is well below the average of 68% for IT companies in the Standard & Poor’s 500 — a 6% yield, which would be an amazing $28 billion annually. Huberty, who has an Overweight rating on Apple shares, and a $630 price target, writes that adding that additional $13 billion annually is ” a viable option given our conservative FCF estimates assume Apple generates $21B of US FCF this year and would still end the year with $36B of US cash on hand.” A stepped-up buyback, for one thing, would boost earnings: “It maintains financial flexibility, and it would improve FY13 EPS outlook as every $5B adds roughly 1% to EPS growth.” And a higher payout overall could draw in value investors: Improved cash return could draw value investors who currently own just 2% of Apple shares versus 12% ownership of large-cap IT software and hardware companies. Growth funds lowered ownership from 45% two years ago to 33% today while value investor ownership only increased from 1% to 2%. Apple shares today are down $1.83, or 0.4%, at $466.07.

Topic.Title: Truth CNBC "infomercial program" doesn't want you to know:

Message.Msg: Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty met with Apple CFO Peter Oppenheimer this week, and she walked away from that meeting with some insight on Apple's plans for both its cash and iPhone line. Ms. Huberty said that Apple could return as much as US$28 billion in cash to shareholders in fiscal 2013, representing a 6 percent yield for shareholders. Doing so, she argued, would, "match the S&P IT sector’s average [free cash flow] payout of 68 percent." The analyst's numbers are based on the fact that Apple's cash hoard increased by $40 billion in fiscal 2012. She also told her clients that, "a lower priced iPhone makes sense," and said that she saw "several signs" that Apple could release such a device.

Message.Title: Judge Grants David Einhorn's Bid to Block Apple Proxy Vote
Message.Msg: thanks in advance Judge. so what's wrong with this new untested management team? By DAN STRUMPF, CHAD BRAY and JESSICA E. LESSIN Apple Inc. AAPL +1.06% said it would pull a contested proposal from its shareholder meeting next Wednesday, after a federal judge granted a bid by Greenlight Capital Inc. to block a vote on the measure. Greenlight founder David Einhorn had opposed Apple's proposal, which relates to the company's ability to issue preferred shares, and had sued to stop it on the grounds that the proposal was incorrectly bundled with other items. Mr. Einhorn wants the vote to act as a referendum on the $137 billion in cash Apple is holding. Friday's ruling by the federal judge gave Mr. Einhorn a victory in his procedural fight with Apple. But more broadly, it draws attention and scrutiny to his ultimate plan to coerce Apple to deliver more of its cash to shareholders. Following Mr. Einhorn's court victory, Apple late Friday said in a statement that the company was "disappointed" with the ruling and described the proxy proposal as "part of our efforts to further enhance corporate governance."

Message.Msg: From $514 to $450. 30 days later, Apple is still at $450. If Apple had to crash further, it would have already. But it did not crash further! Instead it recovered somewhat, and the stock back exactly where we started. The sellers are pretty much done selling. The ones who really wanted to get out, got out! Some buyers came back, but the big buyers are waiting for a bit of good news. Any good news... this stock could fly! What will be the good news? 1. 30 days after the big sell-off is done! Buyers who wanted to show tax losses will return! 2. Apple board is meeting next week. All signs are pointing that Apple would do something! 3. Apple could announce something big and amazing in March! If Apple misses this quarter, they are pretty much done! But would they miss? There's a whole lot riding this quarter. Good luck Longs!!
